answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources you might find helpful as a start to your research.
Chesapeake, VA implemented a hiring freeze last year and decided that, “positions deemed critical to city operations may be granted an exception.”
http://www.wavy.com/dpp/news/local_news/chesapeake/chesapeake-institutes-hiring-freeze
This is a sample hiring freeze and vacancy review policy from Livingston, MI.
http://co.livingston.mi.us/HumanResources/pdfs/2012%20PDFs/Vacancy%20Review%20Final%20Jan%202012.pdf
I also found two other counties that have recently implemented a hiring freeze. You may want to contact them for more inform about their process. 
Fulton County, IL
http://centralillinoisproud.com/fulltext/?nxd_id=221732
Saratoga County, NY
http://poststar.com/news/local/saratoga-county-institutes-hiring-freeze/article_7365c4d0-b261-11e0-adae-001cc4c002e0.html

author: Bruce Langlan
text:
Our town charter specifically grants to the town council "Section 6-5 Administration and Fiduciary Oversight of the Budget. The town council shall provide by ordinance the procedures for administration and fiduciary oversight of the budget." 
One councilor introduced an ordinance that imposes a hiring freeze. The ordinance also allows the town manager to make his case that some hiring is necessary and if the council agrees they would vote to allow the hiring to proceed.
The Town Attorney says that violates the charter yet it is my understanding that hiring frees are a common practice on the federal, state and local levels of government.
I would like to know how common a practice it is in the council/manager form of government and any suggestions for simple ordinance language that would accomplish such. Obviously neither the town manager or town attorney who is suppose to work for the town council as well as the town manager are against such a restriction on the executive branch.
Thank you.
Bruce
title: Hire Freeze Ordinance
